keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to severe flooding in five states caused by heavy rains from remnants of hurricanes.
The state of Veracruz reported 29 deaths, followed by 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and one in Queretaro.
A total of 65 people are still missing, including 43 in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzoya, and President Claudia Sheinbaum played key roles in coordinating the national response.
The floods were triggered by remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which led to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla) with 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively.
Thousands of military troops from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and conduct search and rescue operations.
More than 80% of electricity supply has been restored across the five affected states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
Early estimates show that around 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappearing'.
Mexico’s meteorological alert system failed to issue warnings about the extreme rainfall magnitude, raising concerns about disaster preparedness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding in five Mexican states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—caused at least 64 deaths and left 65 people missing, primarily due to heavy rains from remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. Government officials, including President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua, coordinated a massive military and civil response, deploying thousands of troops to deliver food, water, and aid. Over 100,000 homes were affected, with some areas experiencing near-total destruction. Despite extensive efforts, the national alert system failed to issue early warnings about the extreme rainfall, raising concerns about disaster preparedness and climate resilience.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
